chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Feverish children - risk assessment
chapter.summary: Covers the risk assessment of an infant or child with fever.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth to 5 years.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I assess a febrile infant or child?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If there is any compromise of the airway, breathing, circulation, or consciousness level, telephone 999 to arrange emergency ambulance transfer to Accident and Emergency.
  • Ask about:
    • The onset, duration, and pattern of fever, and method of temperature measurement. Reported parental perception of fever should be accepted as a valid indicator of fever.
      • In children less than 4 weeks of age, use or recommend an electronic thermometer in the axilla.
      • In children aged 4 weeks to 5 years of age, use or recommend either an electronic thermometer or a chemical dot thermometer in the axilla, or an infra-red tympanic thermometer.
      • Note: do not use or recommend forehead thermometers or the oral/rectal route to measure temperature.
    • Any associated symptoms suggesting an underlying cause of fever.
    • Any perinatal complications such as maternal fever and/or premature delivery.
    • Any significant medical conditions, such as known immunosuppression or immunodeficiency.
    • Any recent antipyretic drug and/or antibiotic use.
    • The child's immunization history, and any missed immunizations. See the CKS topic on Immunizations - childhood for more information.
    • Any recent foreign travel, including to areas with a high risk of endemic infectious disease such as malaria. See the CKS topic on Malaria for more information.
    • Any recent contact with people with serious infectious diseases.
    • Parental/carer health beliefs about fever and previous family experience of serious febrile illness (may increase parent/carer anxiety).
  • Use the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) 'traffic light' system, to assess the child's risk of serious illness.
    • Assess the general appearance, temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate, capillary refill time (CRT), and fluid status if the child is seen face-to-face. See the section on the NICE traffic light system for more information.
    • Consider measuring the child's blood pressure if the heart rate or CRT are abnormal, if appropriate equipment and expertise are available.
  • If there are red features suggesting a serious or life-threatening cause of febrile illness, arrange emergency ambulance transfer to Accident and Emergency. These include:
    • Features of sepsis or central nervous system infection, such as bacterial meningitis/meningococcal disease or encephalitis. See the CKS topics on Sepsis and Meningitis - bacterial meningitis and meningococcal disease for more information on emergency management.
    • Features of pneumonia or severe dehydration. See the CKS topic on Cough - acute with chest signs in children for more information.
  • If there are other non life-threatening red features, arrange an urgent (within 2 hours) face-to-face assessment if the infant or child was initially assessed by telephone, to help guide whether urgent hospital admission is needed.
  • If there are amber features (but no red features), arrange a face-to-face assessment if the infant or child was initially assessed by telephone, the urgency depending on clinical judgement, to help guide whether hospital admission is needed.
    • Consider arranging hospital admission if:
      • An infant is younger than 3 months with a suspected urinary tract infection (UTI) and no alternative focus of infection, to obtain a reliable urine specimen and initiate treatment. See the CKS topic on Urinary tract infection - children for more information.
      • The feverish illness has no obvious underlying cause, and the infant or child is unwell for longer than expected for a self-limiting illness.
      • There is significant parental/carer anxiety and/or difficulty coping due to the family/social situation.
    • If the child can be managed at home, provide the parents/carers with safety netting advice by one or more of the following methods, depending on clinical judgement:
      • Advise on warning symptoms and signs and when urgent medical review is needed.
      • Arrange a follow-up appointment in primary care for review.
      • Liaise with other healthcare professionals, including out-of-hours providers, to ensure direct access for the child if further assessment is required.
  • If there are green features (but no amber/red features), the child can usually be managed at home.
  • Kawasaki disease - be aware of the possibility of Kawasaki disease in children with fever that has lasted 5 days or longer. Additional features of Kawasaki disease may include:
    • Bilateral conjunctival injection without exudate.
    • Erythema and cracking of lips; strawberry tongue; or erythema of oral and pharyngeal mucosa.
    • Oedema and erythema in the hands and feet.
    • Polymorphous rash.
    • Cervical lymphadenopathy. 
      • Ask parents or carers about the presence of these features since the onset of fever, because they may have resolved by the time of assessment. Be aware that children under 1 year may present with fewer clinical features Kawasaki disease in addition to fever, but may be at higher risk of coronary artery abnormalities than older children.
  • If the child can be managed at home:
    • Assess for and manage any underlying cause of fever, if appropriate.
      • Consider urine dipstick analysis and urine microscopy and culture if there is unexplained fever and no apparent focus of infection to exclude a UTI. See the CKS topic on Urinary tract infection - children for more information.
    • Advise on the use of paracetamol or ibuprofen to reduce fever if the child is uncomfortable or distressed, and on measures to prevent dehydration. See the CKS topic on Feverish children - management for more information.
      • Advise that routine prophylactic antipyretic drugs do not reduce or prevent recurrent febrile seizures. See the CKS topic on Febrile seizure for more information.
      • Note: do not rely on a decrease (or lack of decrease) in the child's temperature after 1–2 hours following the use of antipyretic therapy, to differentiate between serious and non-serious illness.
    • Provide advice on sources of information and support, such as:
      • The patient information leaflet Fever in children (high temperature) available on the www.patient.info website.
      • The NHS leaflet Fever in children.
    • Provide the parents/carers with safety netting advice on warning symptoms and signs and when medical review is needed.

subChapters.htmlHeader: The NICE traffic light system
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Table 1. The NICE 'traffic light' system for identifying the risk of serious illness in children. Note: an infant or child will fall into the amber or red risk category if they have any of the relevant clinical features.

 

Green (low risk of serious illness)

Amber (intermediate risk of serious illness)

Red (high risk of serious illness)

ColourNormal colour of skin, lips, and tongue.

Pallor of skin, lips, or tongue reported by parent or carer.

Pale, mottled, ashen, or blue skin, lips, or tongue.
Activity

Responding normally to social cues. Content and smiling.

Stays awake or awakens quickly.

Strong normal cry or not crying.

Not responding normally to social cues.

Waking only with prolonged stimulation.

Decreased activity.

Not smiling.

No response to social cues.

Appears ill to a healthcare professional.

Unable to rouse, or if roused does not stay awake.

Weak, high-pitched, or continuous crying.

Respiratory—

Nasal flaring.

Tachypnoea: 6–12 months of age RR* > 50 breaths per minute; > 12 months of age RR* > 40 breaths per minute.

Oxygen saturation ≤ 95% in air.

Crackles on chest auscultation.

Grunting.

Tachypnoea: RR* 60 breaths per minute or more.

Moderate or severe chest indrawing.

Hydration and circulation

Normal skin turgor and eyes.

Moist mucous membranes.

Poor feeding in infants.

Dry mucous membranes.

Capillary refill time of 3 seconds or more.

Reduced urine output (in infants ask about wet nappies).

Tachycardia: >160 beats/minute under 1 year of age; >150 beats/minute 1–2 years of age; >140 beats/minute 2–5 years of age.

Reduced skin turgor.
OtherNone of the amber or red symptoms or signs.

Fever for 5 days or more.

Rigors.

Temperature ≥ 39°C in children 3–6 months of age.

 

Temperature ≥ 38°C in infants 0–3 months of age

Swelling of limb or joint.

Non weight-bearing or not using a limb.

Non-blanching rash†.

Bulging fontanelle†.

Neck stiffness†.

Focal neurological signs†.

Focal seizures.

Status epilepticus‡.

*RR: respiratory rate.

†: signs of meningeal irritation may be subtle or absent in children less than 12–24 months of age [Waruiru and Appleton, 2004; Leung, 2018].

‡: traditionally defined as a seizure that lasts for 30 minutes or longer, or a series of seizures without full recovery in between that last for 30 minutes or longer [ILAE, 1993].

NICE notes that some vaccinations may induce fever in children younger than 3 months.

Data from: [NICE, 2017]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on assessment of the febrile infant or child are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guidelines Feverish illness in children: assessment and initial management in children younger than 5 years [NICE, 2017] and Urinary tract infection in children: diagnosis, treatment and long-term management [NICE, 2018], a US emergency medicine policy document Clinical policy for well-appearing infants and children younger than 2 years of age presenting to the emergency department with fever [Mace, 2016], the Resuscitation Council (UK) guideline Paedatric basic life support [Resuscitation Council (UK), 2015], a Task Force Report of the International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) Commission of Pediatrics Summary of recommendations for the management of infantile seizures [Wilmshurst, 2015], a Cochrane systematic review Prophylactic drug management for febrile seizures in children [Offringa, 2017], analyses of an Australian cohort study [Craig, 2010; De, 2013], a European prospective cohort study [Kerkhof, 2014], and expert opinion in review articles on fever in children [Ishimine, 2013; Richardson, 2015; Rosenfeld-Yehoshua, 2018].

Management of life-threatening signs of illness
  • The recommendation to identify and manage any life-threatening signs of illness in children as a priority is based on the NICE clinical guideline, the Resuscitation Council (UK) guideline, and is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Assessing the child's temperature
  • The recommendations on thermometers and the detection of fever are based on the NICE clinical guideline on feverish illness.
    • The recommendation to accept parental perception of fever as valid is based on studies on the subjective detection of fever by parents and carers, which found the sensitivity of palpation for the detection of fever ranged from 74% to 97%, which is comparable to that reported for axillary and tympanic thermometers.
    • It noted that the different methods of temperature measurement have not been directly compared with each other, but are of comparable cost.
    • It found electronic thermometers are accurate and quick to use but may be expensive.
    • It found that infrared thermometers are quick, non-invasive, and simple to use, but are relatively expensive.
    • Moderate-quality evidence from one study found that axillary measurements of temperature had a sensitivity of 98% in neonates.
    • The recommendation not to use forehead chemical thermometers is based on the fact that they are unreliable, based on moderate-to-low quality evidence from four observational studies.
    • The recommendations not to use oral or rectal temperature measurements are based on a NICE guideline development group Delphi consensus, which noted a lack of evidence on the relative accuracy or ability to detect fever using these routes, and concerns over their safety and acceptability.
Assessing the child's history
  • The recommendations on other factors in the child and family history are based on the NICE clinical guideline on feverish illness and expert opinion in review articles [Ishimine, 2013; Mace, 2016].
    • The identification of additional symptoms suggesting an underlying cause of fever is important to allow appropriate investigation and management in primary or secondary care.
    • The recommendation to ask about perinatal complications such as maternal fever is based on the fact that these are risk factors for serious bacterial infection in neonates and infants up to 3 months of age [Ishimine, 2013].
    • The recommendation to ask about recent antipyretic use is based on the fact that drug treatment in the previous 4 hours may result in a febrile child presenting with a normal or lower temperature when assessed [Mace, 2016]. In addition, NICE notes that children with milder illness may either show greater improvement in clinical condition or a greater reduction in their fever than children with more serious illness, however it is uncertain if this is a valid and reliable indicator of illness severity, and more research is needed.
    • The recommendation to ask about recent antibiotic use is based on the fact these children may have an incompletely treated bacterial infection and may not present with typical clinical features [Ishimine, 2013].
    • The recommendation to ask about immunization history is based on the US emergency medicine policy document [Mace, 2016].
    • The recommendation to identify preterm infants or children with immunodeficiency is based on the fact that sepsis or other serious bacterial infection in these children is associated with an increased risk of complications and significant morbidity or mortality [Ishimine, 2013]. It is also based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
    • The recommendation to ask about parent/carer health beliefs about fever is based on research survey evidence cited in the NICE clinical guideline on feverish illness, that fever is commonly perceived as a potential cause of serious harm, fits, brain damage, and death by caregivers and some healthcare professionals.
    • NICE notes additional features on history which may guide whether hospital admission is appropriate, such as potential infectious contacts or previous parental/carer experience of serious febrile illness. This approach is supported by expert opinion in a review article [Ishimine, 2013].
    • The recommendation to ask about parent/carer anxiety and support is based on the fact that reliable monitoring at home and appropriate accessing of healthcare for medical review is needed if a child is to be safely managed at home following clinical assessment [Mace, 2016].
Using the NICE traffic light clinical assessment tool
  • The majority of fever is caused by self-limiting viral infection, but it can also be a sign of serious bacterial infection, and it can be difficult to distinguish between the two, especially in the early stages of illness. A delayed or missed diagnosis of serious bacterial infection may be life-threatening or cause significant morbidity. Viral and bacterial infections may also co-exist or evolve over time [Craig, 2010; Mace, 2016; Rosenfeld-Yehoshua, 2018].
    • The younger the child, the more difficult it may be to clinically establish a diagnosis and assess the severity of illness [NICE, 2017].
    • Improved recognition, evaluation, and treatment of febrile illness in children may lead to a reduction in mortality from infectious disease. In addition, appropriate risk assessment of children with minor self-limiting illnesses means they do not undergo unnecessary investigations and treatment [NICE, 2017].
  • The recommendation to use the NICE 'traffic light' system to assess and predict a child's risk of serious illness and the need for further investigation and/or monitoring is based on evidence-based reviews identified by NICE, clinical features in the Yale Observation Scale (a pre-existing scoring system), and the clinical experience of the NICE guideline development group [NICE, 2017].
    • NICE assessed multiple heterogeneous studies of variable quality which used different methodologies, temperature cut-offs for study inclusion, study populations, clinical settings, and outcomes. As a result, the data could not be pooled, and it was difficult for the guideline development group to compare evidence from multiple studies for a particular symptom or sign.
      • It identified two scoring systems, the Yale Observational Scale and the Young Infant Observation Score, however neither scale was considered sensitive for the detection of serious bacterial infection. It concluded that the Yale Observation Scale was good at excluding serious illness but was less good at identifying serious illness, and was most useful when combined with a clinical history and examination. Most of the data were in infants younger than 6 months of age, and this data was extrapolated to older children by NICE.
    • NICE conducted an initial systematic review of the relationship between the height of fever and the risk of serious illness, and found the predictive value of a high temperature was poor in general, however a higher predictive value was noted in childer under the age of 6 months.
  • A subsequent systematic review of 11 cohort and case control studies of high fever as a predictor for serious bacterial infection found that infants under 3 months of age with a fever greater than 40°C were at increased risk of serious bacterial infection compared with older children. The pooled data for serious bacterial infection in children over 3 months of age with a fever greater than 40°C compared with children with lower temperature did not find a statistically significant risk difference. The authors noted methodological limitations of a small number of studies and significant heterogeneity of the included studies [Rosenfeld-Yehoshua, 2018].
  • An Australian 2-year prospective cohort study of children under 5 years presenting with a febrile illness (n = 15,781 febrile episodes) analyzed data in order to develop a multi-variable model to distinguish serious bacterial infections from self-limiting non-bacterial illness [Craig, 2010].
    • It found that emergency department clinicians tend to underestimate the likelihood of serious bacterial infection in young febrile children, leading to undertreatment with antibiotics.
  • CKS found two studies which have assessed the validity of the NICE traffic light system in different clinical settings.
    • An Australian retrospective analysis of the same study data found the NICE traffic light system had a test sensitivity of 85.5% and specificity of 28.5% for the detection of any serious bacterial infection (specifically urinary tract infection, pneumonia, and bacteraemia). In particular, it failed to detect 13.8% of serious infections (children classified in the green zone), particularly urinary tract infections. It found that adding urine analysis to the scoring system significantly improved the traffic light system test performance and sensitivity [De, 2013]. CKS notes that NICE recommend considering urine analysis on all children with fever with no apparent focus of infection.
    • A European study of the predictive value of the red features of the NICE traffic light system in identifying serious infection in children presenting with acute illness in various settings in primary care, emergency and paediatric departments (n = 6,260), found that the presence of three or more red features improved the predictive value of serious infection, however the results were not consistent in multiple settings [Kerkhof, 2014].
Management of an infant or child with red features
  • The NICE clinical guideline on feverish illness notes that fever may be the presenting feature of serious bacterial infections such as bacterial meningitis, sepsis, or pneumonia. The clinical features of focal neurological signs, focal seizures, and/or decreased level of consciousness may indicate a diagnosis of herpes simplex encephalitis.
  • The recommendation to assess a child urgently within 2 hours if there are no life-threatening features is based on a NICE guideline development group Delphi consensus which was used to define a specific timeframe for further assessment. NICE notes that the majority of infants and children with one or more red features will be referred for hospital assessment due to the high risk of serious illness.
    • Young children with serious illness may deteriorate within hours of onset, and a period of hospital observation may help to identify and monitor these children in a safe environment.
Management of an infant or child with amber or green features
  • The NICE clinical guideline on feverish illness notes that the majority of febrile illness in children is due to self-limiting viral infections. Children with fever without an apparent source of infection may be a cause for concern, however, as it can be difficult to distinguish between a simple viral infection and life-threatening bacterial infection in this group. A period of observation in hospital may be helpful to differentiate non-serious from serious illness.
  • The recommendation to arrange admission for any infant under 3 months of age with a suspected urinary tract infection (UTI) is based on the NICE clinical guideline on UTI in children.
  • The clinical feature of fever lasting more than 5 days is significant as this may indicate a diagnosis of Kawasaki disease if associated with other typical symptoms and signs [NICE, 2017].
  • The clinical features of swelling of a joint or limb and/or non-weight bearing or non-use of a limb are significant as these may indicate bone or joint infection such as septic arthritis or osteomyelitis [NICE, 2017].
  • The recommendation to safety net and/or reassess the child is based on the need to check for any clinical deterioration and to assess for new symptoms or signs suggesting an underlying cause for fever [NICE, 2017].
Management of a child at home
  • The recommendation to assess for an underlying cause of fever is based on the NICE clinical guideline on feverish illness.
    • The recommendation to consider urine analysis to exclude a UTI is based on the fact that this is a common source of fever and may present with non-specific or no additional symptoms in young infants and children [Ishimine, 2013; NICE, 2018]. In addition, the US emergency medicine policy document includes fever duration of greater than 24 hours and no obvious source of infection as clinical risk factors for UTI in well-appearing infants and children aged 2 months to 2 years [Mace, 2016].
  • The recommendations on the use of antipyretic drugs are based on the NICE clinical guideline on feverish illness, a Cochrane systematic review [Offringa, 2017], an ILAE Task Force Report [Wilmshurst, 2015], and expert opinion in a review article [Richardson, 2015].
    • The recommendation not to use prophylactic antipyretic drugs to prevent febrile seizures is based on a Cochrane systematic review of 30 randomized trials (n = 4256) which studied the continuous or intermittent use of prophylactic antipyretic, antiepileptic, or other drugs compared with each other, placebo, or no treatment. It found no evidence for the intermittent use of ibuprofen, diclofenac, or paracetamol compared with placebo in preventing recurrent febrile seizures. This approach is supported by the ILAE Task Force Report.
    • The recommendation not to use a response to antipyretic therapy alone as a means to differentiate between serious and non-serious illness is based on the NICE clinical guideline on feverish illness which assessed very low-quality evidence from five prospective and three retrospective studies, and concluded that there is no good evidence to support or refute the recommendation, and more research is needed in this area.
  • The recommendation to safety net and/or reassess the child is based on the need to check for any clinical deterioration and to assess for new symptoms or signs suggesting an underlying cause for fever [NICE, 2017].
Kawasaki disease
  • The recommendations to be aware of the possibility of Kawasaki disease is based on the NICE guideline Fever in under 5s: assessment and initial management [NICE, 2019].
